properties.Title: Update: A High Water Advisory Is Being Continued For The Saskatchewan And Carrot Rivers Near The Town Of The Pas
properties.Summary:
Description: Update: This is a Manitoba Emergency Alert. Manitoba Infrastructure's Hydrologic Forecast Centre continues to issue a High Water Advisory for the Saskatchewan and Carrot Rivers near the Town of The Pas. River levels are currently rising which may cause ice jamming. If you are in the affected area, be watchful of local waterways as flooding is likely to occur. Do not attempt to cross fast flowing waters or waters of unknown depth. Avoid flooded areas. Follow all directions by the local authorities. Listen for updates and take all necessary precautions to stay safe. Up-to-date information is available at www.gov.mb.ca/flooding and www.manitoba511.ca or stay tuned to local media.
Expires: 2019-04-18T10:45:00-05:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Manitoba Emergency Measures Organization, 2019-04-17T10:43:54-05:00, 6AF0ACAC-E23D-5EFC-1F46-D013549C1CE1
Area: The Saskatchewan and Carrot Rivers near the Town of The Pas
properties.Author: Manitoba Emergency Measures Organization

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, heavy at times is expected. The frozen ground has a reduced ability to absorb this rainfall. ### Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Update On The Precautionary Drinking Water Advisory Is Being Issued By The Weyburn Rural Utility Board
properties.Summary:
Description: Update on t Precautionary drinking water alert. Testing has been done and we are awaiting test results . Weyburn Rural Utility Board precautionary drinking water advisory alert for all the rural water drinking water lines in their system is still in affect. This advisory is for the entire community and for any individuals who may access water from the Weyburn Rural Utility Board water system. This advisory is in effect due to an upset at the city treatment plant and is in effect until further notice.
Expires: 2019-04-17T17:00:00-06:00
Originated from CAP Alert: SK Weyburn Rural Utility Board, 2019-04-17T08:02:53-06:00, 18E72E0A-CE67-4250-8B21-5C6F32491684
Area: RM's of Weyburn, Brokenshell, Griffin, Lomond, Wellington, Village of McTaggart
properties.Author: SK Weyburn Rural Utility Board

properties.Title: Update: Flood Watch Continued For All Points Along The Roseau River
properties.Summary:
Description: Update: This is a Manitoba Emergency Alert. Manitoba Infrastructure's Hydrologic Forecast Centre continues to issue a Flood Watch for all points along the Roseau River due to expected high water flows. If you are in the affected area, be watchful of local waterways as flooding is likely to occur. Do not attempt to cross fast flowing waters or waters of unknown depth. Avoid flooded areas. Follow all directions given by local authorities. Listen for updates and take all necessary precautions to stay safe. Up-to-date information is available at www.gov.mb.ca/flooding and www.manitoba511.ca or stay tuned to local media.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, heavy at times, is expected to start Friday. Rainfall amounts of 40 to 60 mm are possible by Sunday. This rainfall is the result of multiple low pressure systems tracking over the region. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, heavy at times is expected. The frozen ground has a reduced ability to absorb this rainfall. Rain will develop this evening or overnight and continue into Friday morning. The heaviest rain is expected Thursday morning and afternoon. Total rainfall amounts of 20 to 40 mm are possible by Friday morning. Rain will taper to scattered showers or flurries Friday morning. This rainfall is the a result of a Colorado Low that will track over Northeastern Ontario Thursday. ### Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-04-18T11:10:56-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-04-17T19:11:56-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3585080160.2019
Area: Greater Sudbury and vicinity, Elliot Lake - Ranger Lake, New Liskeard - Temagami, Blind River - Thessalon, Espanola - Killarney, Manitoulin Island
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: An extended period of rain is expected during the Easter weekend. Rain along with warmer temperatures will develop Thursday into Friday and continue through to Sunday as a series of low pressure systems pass west of New Brunswick. The rain should be mixed with some snow during the start of the precipitation Thursday night. Rainfall amounts of 20 to 40 mm are likely Thursday night and Friday. Additional amounts are expected Saturday and Sunday bringing the total rainfall over the three days to 50 to 80 mm with a possibility of 100 mm or more over portions of the northwest. These forecast amounts will be refined closer to the weekend. This rainfall combined with snowmelt will enhance the threat of flooding. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.
Expires: 2019-04-18T02:56:49-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-04-17T18:57:49-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3611897281.2019
Area: Woodstock and Carleton County, Stanley - Doaktown - Blackville Area, Edmundston and Madawaska County, western half of Restigouche County, Campbellton and eastern half of Restigouche County, Grand Falls and Victoria County, Mount Carleton - Renous Highway, Bathurst and Chaleur Region, Miramichi and area, Acadian Peninsula

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, heavy at times is expected. The frozen ground has a reduced ability to absorb this rainfall. Rain will develop this evening or overnight and continue into Friday. The heaviest rain is expected Thursday afternoon and evening. Total rainfall amounts of 30 to 50 mm are possible by Friday morning. Periods of rain will continue Friday with an additional 20 to 30 mm of rainfall possible before tapering to scattered showers Friday night or Saturday. This rainfall is the a result of a Colorado Low that will track over Northeastern Ontario Thursday. ### Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. An intense low pressure system east of Newfoundland will bring snow, strong northwesterlies and blowing snow over the area today. Conditions should improve this afternoon. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2019-04-17T19:59:35-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-04-17T07:52:35-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0539658193.2019
Area: Inverness County - Mabou and north
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A long period of snowfall with total amounts of about 25 cm is expected. A deep low pressure system over the Gulf of Alaska will approach the region tonight, accompanied by a strong southeasterly flow which will force a lot of moisture along the highway up to Chilkat Pass. Snow levels will oscillate between 500 and 700 metres, thus precipitation will fall exclusively as rain near Pleasant Camp and as heavy snow near Chilkat Pass with a phase transition in between. Lighter snow will also occur north of the pass, generally ranging from 5 to 10 cm. The highest snow amounts are expected near the pass where up to 25 cm should accumulate tonight and Thursday. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather in British Columbia or Yukon, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or YTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm or #YTStorm.
Expires: 2019-04-18T09:47:39-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-04-17T17:48:39-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3855137583.2019
Area: Haines Road - Haines Junction to Pleasant Camp
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. Strong northerly winds gusting between 80 and 100 km/h will continue today then slowly diminish tonight. ### Loose objects may be tossed by the wind and cause injury or damage. Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-04-17T23:03:12-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-04-17T13:15:12-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2342255023.2019
Area: Bay of Exploits, Bonavista North, Green Bay - White Bay
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Blowing Snow Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Poor visibility in snow and blowing snow is expected or occurring in some locations. Snow and strong northerly winds gusting between 80 and 100 km/h are expected today. While widespread whiteout conditions are not expected with this event, visibilities will be significantly reduced in blowing snow, especially over exposed areas and during periods of heavier snowfall. Additional snowfall accumulations could still approach 10 cm in some areas, with lesser amounts along parts of coast. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility in some locations. Blowing snow advisories are issued when winds are expected to create blowing snow giving poor visibility to 800 metres or less for at least 3 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-04-17T23:11:56-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-04-17T13:14:56-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1868623494.2019
Area: Grand Falls-Windsor and vicinity, Bay of Exploits, Bonavista North, Gander and vicinity, Green Bay - White Bay
properties.Author: Environment Canada
